Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They are expected to deep clean every room, ensuring all areas are thoroughly sanitized.
Story: It’s Saturday morning, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re doing well. Call us when you can!” I know she and Dad expect me to check in, especially on weekends. I glance at the clock—my shift as a housekeeping cleaner just started, and today’s schedule is packed. The supervisor handed me a list: every room needs a deep clean, top to bottom, no shortcuts. I can already feel the pressure mounting as I scrub the bathroom tiles, my phone vibrating in my pocket with another message. I want to step outside, call my parents, and reassure them I’m okay, but I also know if I fall behind, the supervisor will notice, and the rooms won’t be up to standard. My mind races between the guilt of not being the attentive son my parents hope for and the anxiety of not meeting the expectations at work. I stare at my phone, torn, the mop heavy in my hand, caught between two worlds that both need me right now.
